newsitem.title: BELGIUM: IMF welcomes Belgium's economic reforms.
newsitem.headline: IMF welcomes Belgium's economic reforms.

text.p: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) said on Wednesday it welcomed Belgium's economic reforms, but warned that unemployment would remain high in the long-term.
"Economic activity is continuing to accelerate," the IMF said in a statement, adding that inflation was well under control and the external current account remained very strong.
But the IMF made no mention of Belgium's massive debts and measures to reduce them -- crucial if the country is to qualify to join its European Union partners in creating a single currency in 1999.
The IMF forecast GDP to rise by 1.4 percent in 1996 and 2.2-2.5 percent in 1997.
It urged Belgium to press ahead with labour market reforms and to focus on the employment implications of wage settlements.

"With appropriate wage moderation, employment should expand and unemployment decrease over the course of the next two years, but long-term unemployment will remain at a very high level," the IMF said.
It added that incentives needed to be strengthened to increase flexibility of the labour market, while maintaining an adequate social safety net.

"Key reforms should include more flexible wage contracts: further targeted cuts in employers' social security contributions; stronger training; a moderation of severance payments to reduce the deterrent to new hiring," it said.
